intro: Prunus americana var. nigra, commonly known as the black cherry, is a deciduous tree native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its dark, glossy leaves and small, edible fruits that ripen in the fall. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–40 feet, with a spreading crown and smooth, gray bark. Its flowers are white and appear in early spring before the leaves, contributing to its ornamental value. The plant is often found in moist, well-drained soils along streams and in woodlands.
